DAVID ASMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: That does it for BULLS AND BEARS. Thanks for joining us.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO AND CO-FOUNDER, FACEBOOK: We didn't take a broad enough view of our responsibility and that was a mistake and I'm sorry for it.

SEN. AMY KLOBUCHAR, (D) MINNESOTA: I never heard of another company that was actually putting stuff out against elected officials as we now know they did to members of the intelligence committee.

SHERYL SANDBERG, COO, FACEBOOK: We did not do enough to protect people's data. I'm really sorry for that. Mark is really sorry for that.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I believe it's government's responsibility to help create rules that yield a better and more fair bargain for the American people.

KLOBUCHAR: They simply just can't run this like the Wild West when in fact they have got -- they are hurting people, they are potentially breaking the law, and we have to put some rules in place. I hope that in this coming year we'll do that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Senate Democrats now face a painful reckoning with Democrats friends at Facebook. They fired off a letter to CEO Mark Zuckerberg asking, " you, Facebook, are you undermining democracy?" That's a quote. "Are you using your massive data collection to get information to undermine your critics and even elected officials doing scrutiny at Facebook?" The senators ask the Justice Department to broaden its probe as Mark Zuckerberg now says Facebook is, quote, "at war with its critics."

But the real war is actually inside Facebook. Finger pointing. Lame shifting. Tensions with COO Sheryl Sandberg and Mark Zuckerberg. We've got more details tonight.

Democratic New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio creating yet another controversy saying he loves Amazon but he hates Wal-Mart. Again, should politicians be picking winners and losers? We've got that debate.

And we've got on the Florida recount circus. A top official resigning. Also, the new threat to America's military. This one is in our own backyard. The Weekly Standard's Fred Barnes weighs in.

Plus, the mayor of Tijuana, Mexico agreeing with President Trump saying there are criminals in the illegal immigrant caravan. A surprising new government date shows 500 criminals potentially in the caravan flow. Former White House press secretary Sean Spicer is here on that.

Well, thank you so much for joining us. Thank you for watching. Money, politics, we've got the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. THE EVENING EDIT starts right now.

We check your 401K the Dow plunging 400 points. Trade fight with China, Boeing, had took some hits. Big tech drags down the market as things at Facebook continue to go from bad to terrible. So bad that Apple's Tim Cook warns the tech crowd overall. Watch out, regulation is coming.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: I am not a big fan of regulation. I'm a big believer in the free market. But we have to admit when the free market isn't working and it hasn't worked here. And I think it's inevitable that there will be some level of regulation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Worry about Democrat senators asking the Justice Department to widen its probe into Facebook. The senators ratcheting this fight up to a whole new level.

In the senator's letter to Facebook the senators asking hey, you, Facebook, you used outside contractors to retaliate against your critics by spreading inflammatory information about your critics.

So, have you, Facebook, have you ever used your own data platform to collect information to use against your critics including elected officials, elected officials who scrutinize you, including leaks to the media. All of this in possible violation of campaign laws.

Let's bring in one of the smartest guys around. He's Wall Street Journal assistant editor, James Freeman. These are pretty serious charges, James. By the way, thanks for joining us.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Yes. Well, you introduce like that, so I'll show up any time.

Yes, they are serious. As you said a lot of money, a lot of politics here. I guess some --I think Consumers ought to be wary here. They ought to be wary that there is some kind of a big deal between Silicon Valley and Washington to regulate this industry. It may sound good, but I think a lot of downside if you prevent competition against Facebook which is normally what regulation does.

MACDONALD: So, you are saying the market can fix the problem.

FREEMAN: I would hope so. You know, this question of Tim Cook there saying the market failed. I don't think so. I think we all know consumers that we've been trading information about ourselves in return for a lot of free services from Facebook--

MACDONALD: Yes.

FREEMAN: -- for years. You know, maybe this is a helpful reminder to people.

MACDONALD: Al right. I know that you are pretty cynical about Facebook's aptitude to do things.

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: I would be myself as optimistic--

MACDONALD: I know you're optimistic.

FREEMAN: -- about what the markets can do.

MACDONALD: I understand what you mean. But here is the thing. Zuckerberg is under fire. The Senate Democrats are saying hey, you can't regulate yourself.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MACDONALD: I'm not -- the Wall Street Journal and the New York Times stories about Facebook have been bombshells. Nobody knew the scope of what Facebook was doing to undermine its critics, right?

So, now Facebook is saying we're at war with our critics at the same time that they really can't regulate themselves. That's the issue, right.

FREEMAN: Well, I don't think any business is going to regulate itself. I think talk about self-regulation is kind of na‹ve. What you want is market discipline, you want customers with the ability to regulate the behavior of the provider. And if this kind of a wakeup call to people it would be more demanding as customers to look for other options, maybe that's a good thing.

But I think a lot of what's happening here is especially you mentioned that all those you've showed the Democrats really leading this attack, they are very upset that Facebook did not agree with their analysis that Russians meddling online swayed the 2016 or swung the 2016 election from--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: But they are pretty powerful. They got a lot of power.

FREEMAN: They are.

MACDONALD: What if they are using their data platform to undermine elected officials who scrutinize it. That's a heavy charge. That's a big deal.

FREEMAN: Yes. I also I would worry big time about what they're doing in terms of censorship. They have thousands of editors now, are they knocking out voices they don't like. I think maybe Congress might want to relook at the 1990's decision to give social media platforms kind of protections that normal companies don't have.

MACDONALD: It's a good question.

FREEMAN: And let's -- that is a good question.

MACDONALD: Yes. We'll have you back on it.

FREEMAN: It sounds good.

MACDONALD: I'll continue to say you're terrific. Thank you for--

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: Any time.

MACDONALD: OK. Switching gears. After last week's announcement that Amazon will open one of its two new headquarters in New York City, Democrat Mayor Bill de Blasio basically said that he likes Amazon but he doesn't like Wal- Mart. He does not like Wal-Mart's behavior when it comes to labor and the environment. That's the mayor said. He even took a swipe at the Walton family over their politics.

Let's bring in the Daily Signal's Kelsey Harkness and former D.C. Chamber of Commerce chairman, Scott Bolden. Good to see both you guys.

SCOTT BOLDEN, FORMER CHAIR, D.C. CHAMBER OF COMMERCE: Good seeing you.

KELSEY HARKNESS, SENIOR REPORTER, DAILY SIGNAL: Good to see you.

MACDONALD: Kelsey, what do you think of this story.

HARKNESS: This should be frightening to all Americans regardless of your political perspective because what the mayor of New York City basically just said is that he didn't allow a company into New York City in part because of the owners of that company's political views.

Furthermore, I think there's a lot of hypocrisy going on here because of course Amazon and Wal-Mart have very different business model models. But ultimately what they're doing is attempting to provide items in mass to Americans at cheaper prices. And for them to roll out the red carpet for Amazon, giving them billions of dollars in tax incentives--

MACDONALD: Yes.

HARKNESS: -- and then block at Wal-Mart I think that is so hypocritical.

MACDONALD: You know, Scott, Mayor de Blasio he said that Wal-Mart undermines local retailers but then Amazon has been criticizing that too, right? Even though Amazon does have a lot of small businesses on its own web site.

BOLDEN: Yes.

MACDONALD: Other retailers can't really compete with it. You know what I mean, Scott?

BOLDEN: Yes. But let me tell you. The biggest difference I see is that Amazon is an internet sensation retailer as opposed to a big box retailer like Wal-Mart. I'm not saying one is better than the other.

I'm saying each company when they come to your jurisdiction, I live in D.C. and we've got Wal-Mart and now the Amazon is coming in Crystal City, they have to negotiate with politicians because they need land, they need space, they impact the economy, and a lot of them need tax incentives and that gives politicians license to either extract more or to comment or to pick and choose.

I didn't say it was right, but I got to tell you it happens all the time.

MACDONALD: Yes.

BOLDEN: And these are complicated negotiations that start a long time before you to either see a Wal-Mart or you see the headquarters or second headquarters for Amazon.

MACDONALD: Yes, I hear you, Scott. And Kelsey, Scott makes an important point here. The other issue too and the other side of that and I want to hear what Scott says about this.

What if the, you know, Albany or the state capitals just flatten the tax structure instead of handing out goodies in the form of tax breaks, a lot of Democrats work at Wal-Mart. What if New Yorkers do want a Wal-Mart too, you know. There's all sorts of angles here, right, Kelsey?

HARKNESS: Absolutely. I think that's the biggest irony of this whole Amazon H.Q. two story is that in many ways it makes the case for deregulating the economy and lowering taxes. New York would have had to incentivize Amazon to go there had they had an economy like you see in Texas that's already working. Instead, they had to basically bag Amazon via a lot of cronyism. I would argue to get them to another city.

MACDONALD: What do you--

(CROSSTALK)

BOLDEN: Well--

HARKNESS: And taxpayers are the ones who are paying for that.

MACDONALD: Go ahead, Scott.

BOLDEN: Yes, flattening the tax rate in any jurisdiction simply wouldn't be enough and it would take a long time for it to even, even out. The reality is this. You're going to have these negotiations and you are going to have these competitions and the municipalities of the states have the power to give these tax incentives and tax breaks like they would any other company, if you will.

MACDONALD: I hear you.

BOLDEN: And in giving those tax breaks what they get in return, at least in Crystal City is a $5 billion investment that improves infrastructure, the airport and what have you. It's hard to turn that down. It's hard to say they shouldn't be competition.

MACDONALD: And Scott, you have been in the forefront of this, you at the Chamber of Commerce in D.C. you've seen this first-hand even in the front trenches of this. Quickly, I just want to -- Kelsey, I just want to ask Scott a follow up.

The argument about this too, Scott, is what about the guys and gals in upstate New York who are basically are paying for Amazon to come here twice what people in Virginia are paying and they're kind of, you know, saying, hey what about us in upstate New York?

BOLDEN: Well, it's the cost of living difference and a lot of environmental and environmental economics what I call, and so those numbers are going to be different. If I was a partner at a law firm like mine in New York I'd probably be making more money than here because it's a different market.

MACDONALD: Kelsey, Scott, you've been great. Thank you so much. I appreciate it.

HARKNESS: Thank you.

BOLDEN: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Now to more big executives behaving badly. The fallout mounting after the chairman of Nissan auto legend, Carlos Ghosn arrested in Japan on charges of hiding millions of dollars in compensation from Japanese authorities. Potentially French authorities, as well also alleged to have padded his expense account use an investment fund. Also, with the hiding of his compensation avoiding the tax man.

Hillary Vaughn with the details. Hillary?

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Liz. Well, disappointment indignation and despair. Those are the words from Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa reacting to the news that their chairman Carlos Ghosn had been arrested following a long internal investigation at the company that reveal that the chairman frauded them by using company assets for his own use. Also misusing company investment and underreporting his salary for several years by about 44 million in U.S. dollars.

In a shocking emotional hour and half talk to the press the CEO try to put as much distance between Ghosn and the rest of the company as possible, really framing this as a betrayal as the result of a long regime of power under Ghosn that really didn't have any checks and balances in place.

So, the CEO is saying he's going to seriously reflect on what changes need to be made at the company to make sure that this does not happen again. He's also trying to reassure two other automakers that are kind of caught up in all of this. You have Mitsubishi and Renault, the French car company that is in the partnership and Ghosn was really at the head of all of this.

So Saikawa promising that this three-partnership alliance will not be jeopardized as a result of this, saying they will try to minimize any confusion. He also says that they're going to have to correct their securities report that the company published because Ghosn lied to regulators about how much his salary was.

You also have Saikawa saying he can't promise that there's going to be zero impact on their sales because of this controversy. So he's not ruling out the possibility that Nissan may file a civil lawsuit against Ghosn for this entire scandal and his misconduct at the company that really is cause shareholders to suffer some incredible losses.

The board is set to meet Thursday to officially remove him from the board. Liz.

MACDONALD: Thank you, Hillary. A quick check in the market. The Dow, the NASDAQ, and the S&P were all down today. We're going to stay in that story for you throughout the hour.

To the battle for the border, homeland security now estimates -- estimates, rather, 500 criminals are in the caravans headed to the border. Fox News William La Jeunesse is in Tijuana, Mexico with more. William?

WILLIAM LA JEUNESSE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Well, Liz, I am at the San Isidro port of entry. And earlier today, for the first time ever, the United States shut down this border because they believed and said that the migrants were going to storm this area and go to the vehicle lanes in the United States, so they closed it. They brought an additional K-rails like you see here, and barb wire.

But I want to say this, and I think we have some video from that we shot yesterday. You know, Mexico has his invisible river of migrants coming up from Central America. They have had for generations using it as a stepping off for the United States.

Well, yesterday, about 1,000 Mexicans protested those illegal immigration, throwing bottles and cans. So, riot police shouting via to Mexico saying Hondurans go home, immigration yes, invaders no. And then they storm a police barricade outside of migrant shelter.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You see people, you know, within the migrant caravan smoking weed, drinking, throwing rocks at the cops, causing chaos.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Some of these people that are coming into this with these caravans are committing crimes, and so we are protesting. I am protesting that we want the government to take control.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JEUNESSE: So, critics say these activists are leading the caravan giving them false hope that's a mistake they cannot easily cross illegally and the asylum claims is going to be five weeks away. They are in shelters now after just days looking like a refugee camp of human waste and misery. Supporters. however, say, Mexico owes them hospitality and protection.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It feels like they invaded and that was not the correct way, but I know all of them are not like that.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We're here for work to have a better life and no trouble. We're not trouble makers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JEUNESSE: So, about 6,000 migrants from that caravan are now in Tijuana Department of Homeland securities as there are 10,000 right along the border, and you see from those follow-on copycat caravans, Liz, but this one particularly how they came their numbers seem to awaken the silent, but now vocal minority against them. Liz.

MACDONALD: Great report. William La Jeunesse, thank you so much. I appreciate it, sir.

We have former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer with us tonight. He is now the senior advisor of the America First Action PAC. Coming up, he will be talking about the caravan crisis and the president's threat to shut down the government if he does not get money for his border wall.

In other headline news, Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi dropping the hammer on Walgreens and CBS alleging they have roles in fueling the opioid crisis gripping the country. Basically, they were added to a previously filed lawsuit targeting opioid distributors and manufacturers.

And in case you missed it, look at this video during the Macau Grand Prix over the weekend. A driver lost control of her race car driving head-on into a fence, it went airborne. That driver is Sophia Floersch. She's only 17 years old. Gracefully she survived the crash, but she fractured her spine. She is undergoing surgeries.

And to a grizzly scene for Washington Redskins quarterback Alex Smith, he broke two bones in his leg. The 34-year-old Smith underwent surgery. McCoy replaced him in the game, almost led the Redskins to a comeback win over the Houston Texans but the Texans won.

Coming up, Florida officials had damaged the state election legitimacy by turning the recount into a lawless circus. Broward County official Brenda Snipes resigns after a cascade of problems with this official. The question now is this a warm-up for the 2020 presidential race? We've got the details.

Plus, we dig deeper into the deadly Northern California fires. Eighty dead, nearly 1,000 missing and it continues to look worse and worse for Democrat Governor Jerry Brown.

We'll be right back. Stay there.

MACDONALD: Scenes from California too harrowing to believe. Eighty dead, nearly 1000 missing. And this year alone upwards of 5,600 fires have burned 2,100 square miles in California. That's bigger than the size of Delaware, it's twice the size of Rhode Island.

This as a new PG&E information is coming to light. That utility now admits the problems with the second power line on the morning that the fire started in Butte County in Northern California. They admitted it late last week. California officials have taken into custody equipment from PG&E. Fire investigators are on the scene.

And questions are mounting for Governor Jerry Brown. He recently signed off on legislation protecting utilities like PG&E. And former top executives at that utility are part of Jerry Brown's top staff.

With me now on the phone is Scott McLean of the California Department of forestry and fire protection. Scott, thank you so much. I hear that you guys now face 4 inches of rain is there a problem now with mudslides. What's this going to do for you guys, and the recovery, Scott.

SCOTT MCLEAN, INFORMATIONOFFICER, CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FORESTRY AND FIRE PROTECTION: There's a lot of different predictions out there. Anywhere from an inch to 4 inches and then hoping we're going to see an inch if not two.

Sue of the rain there's a couple of things that case a problem. Keep in mind that where the firefighters are working currently on, they can't fire. They're working on the south, southeast corner of that fire. Heavy terrain, basically mountain, they are dealing with steep topography inaccessible in some areas. And we basically cut roads and with bulldozers so you have dig roads right now and dig trail.

So, unfortunately when the rain comes it's going to turn to it to mud so those firefighters on top of houses, they are already dealing be are going to be dealing with trying to get in and out of those areas.

MACDONALD: Yes. Scott. PG&E and Governor Brown have been in the spotlight. Consumer Watchdog's president Jamie Court he was in Los Angeles. He was on our show. Let's take a listen to what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAMIE COURT, CEO, CONSUMER WATCHDOG: The governor has been a very big partition for PG&E and the other utilities in the state. His top aides have come from PG&E. He's gotten millions of dollars from the three investor- owned utilities and he's protected them.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Your take on less that, Scott.

MCLEAN: I won't address that due to the ongoing investigation and (Inaudible) taking at this time.

MACDONALD: PG&E customers may have ending -- end up footing the bill for the liability claims. The company may turn to its own customers to help cover the cost it could turn into a rate increase for customers, Scott. What's your reaction to that?

MCLEAN: Again, I can only discuss the fire aspect of that. I don't know the PG&E business.

MACDONALD: OK. Here is the fire aspect. This is all over the California newspapers and California state have said this. Seventeen of the 21 major fires in Northern California, according to state official in California have been blamed on PG&E. What is your take on that?

MCLEAN: Again, due to the ongoing legal aspect of those, I cannot -- I will not discuss.

MACDONALD: Well, how are the firefighters doing, sir?

MCLEAN: Firefighters as you can imagine, you talk about the weather it's 30-degree weather, first thing in the morning during the first night as well, so they're dealing with the weather. They are working 24-hour shifts. They are doing a fantastic job.

Keep in mind the first day Thursday morning these firefighters as they arrived to this instance were put in to rescue mode rescuing thousands and thousands of people. They're just phenomenal. They're tired, they're getting the job done.

MACDONALD: It's believable. We'll stay on the story. Scott, thank you so much for being on the show with us tonight. We appreciate it.

MCLEAN: Thank you.

MACDONALD: We're going to be right back. Stay right there.

MACDONALD: Welcome back. We're coming into the bottom of the hour.

After nearly two weeks and multiple recounts, Florida's recount circus finally over. Republican Governor Rick Scott defeating Democrat incumbent Bill Nelson for the Senate. And Republican Congressman Ron DeSantis winning the governorship over Democrat Andrew Gillum.

Also, this as a Broward County's election chief Brenda Snipes resigns.

Fox News Phil Keating has the story for us. Phil?

PHIL KEATING, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes. Can you imagine 12 long days of counting and recounting and lawsuits, but yes, 2018 Florida election is finally over. And here in beleaguered Broward County, the much-maligned supervisor of elections will soon be gone as well.

Aside from the actual races themselves, the other big election winners were all the people, locally and nationally, who have been demanding Broward Elections Chief Brenda Snipes resign or be removed after 15 years in office. Election problems have plagued her career, misplacing ballots, losing ballots, et cetera.

And this year, the nation again watched Broward messed it up, missing the recount deadline to upload the painstakingly second round of results by just two minutes.

In Snipes' resignation letter, she writes, "although I have enjoyed this work tremendously over these many elecion cycles, both large and small, I am ready to pass the torch." She sent that letter up to the secretary of state's office in Tallahassee. She was appointed to this position by then Governor Jeb Bush.

And so the next supervisor of elections here to replace her because Snipes is stepping down on January 4th will be a short-term fill-in because Snipes' term expires in 2020. Twenty-twenty happens to be enormously important presidential election year and both parties really want to have somebody competent and some efficiency in the Broward County Department of Elections for that big race two years from now.

So Snipes will be gone in January and there is already at least three people throwing their name in the ring to be the next temporary supervisor of elections.

MACDONALD: Phil Keating. Great to see you, Phil. Thank you so much. Let's bring in Fred Barnes of The Weekly Standard. He is the executive editor there. I mean, this has been one lawless circus, Fred.

FRED BARNES, EXECUTIVE EDITOR, WEEKLY STANDARD: Well, it is, and it has been that for a while. I don't think it is going to be dramatically better in 2020. I mean, they are just -- after the election, there are a lot of ballots sitting around. You have provisional ballots. You have absentee ballots. You have mail ballots. They are all over the place. There are boxes of them.

And of course Democrats like to have some running room after the election where they can see what's there. In some cases, I suspect decide which are legitimate ballots and which are not. Republicans would like everything to stop on election day. Nothing after that or as little as possible.

Particularly, in the two big Democratic counties that have so many people, Palm Beach County and Broward County, they fear that Democrats are going to pull some tricks.

MACDONALD: You know, to your point, Fred, you make a good point, I mean, even CNN's John King said the Democrats were hoping the courts, the judges will bend the laws for the Democrats.

BARNES: Sure.

MACDONALD: And Fred, what's so interesting, I like your take on this, here is what The Washington Post's Marc Thiessen pointed out last week. Democrats, what they were actually doing to break the laws and bend them, they were asking things, like they were asking judges to change the Florida laws, to include ineligible votes.

They were blowing off deadlines including late vote by mail ballots that arrived after the deadline, asked those be counted. The mismatched signatures, they are supposed to be fixed, Fred, by 5:00 p.m. the day before the election.

BARNES: Right.

MACDONALD: Democrats pushing to get those counted. Now, federal prosecutors looking into Democrat Florida officials urging voters to fix their ballots after election day. Fred, this is about blowing up deadlines, isn't it?

BARNES: It is. It will probably happen again. It's been done before. And certainly the fact that judges will go along with blowing up deadlines and letting things happen, vote counting and so on to happen after the election, days, weeks after the election, that just encourages it to be tried again.

MACDONALD: You know, Fred, you have been such an astute observer of politics for so long and you've helped the country with so much of your insights. I am not just blowing smoke here. I have read your columns for a very long time. What is your chief worry? What is you major concern about the 2020 presidential race when it comes to just what we had to go through with Florida?

BARNES: Well, Florida, I think, stands out for a couple of reasons. Most states will not like Florida. I live in Virginia and there has never really been any problems with the honesty of elections, and I think that's true in many, many states.

But there are still pockets in cities all around the country where people don't feel they can go as vote watchers and be safe. It's a problem that I think -- it's something we have in politics. It is still going to be there. In a close election, it can decide things.

MACDONALD: I'm worried about copycats. Other states doing what Florida did, right, Fred? Final point.

BARNES: Absolutely.

MACDONALD: Yeah.

BARNES: Except a number of these states already do it.

MACDONALD: That's a good point. Fred Barnes, you're terrific. Come back soon.

BARNES: OK.

MACDONALD: Coming up, again, we're going to return to this story, protesters in Tijuana, Mexico taking to the streets of Mexico, saying no to the caravan, pointing out all sorts of problems within that caravan.

The media has not stayed on the story about what exactly is going on inside the caravan. Now, the mayor of Tijuana, he is agreeing with President Trump. The Tijuana mayor is saying yes, there are criminals in there.

We have Sean Spicer, former White House press secretary. He is now with America First Action PAC. He is coming up next on that.

But first, right now might be exactly the wrong time to cut defense spending. It could happen. I'm going to tell you what is going on there. Stay with us.

MACDONALD: Well, it's Thanksgiving. We give thanks to our military, our soldiers. We want to get them more money, more help. President Trump, he did ask each cabinet agency including defense to cut five percent or more from their budgets. That was before an alarming new report found that the American military could possibly actually lose wars with Russia and China. So the question tonight is, is it the wrong time to cut defense spending?

Joining me now is former senior military intelligence officer on the FBI Joint National Terrorism Task Force, Steve Rogers. Great to see you, Steve.

STEVE ROGERS, FORMER SENIOR MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER, FBI JOINT NATIONAL TERRORISM TASK FORCE: Pleasure to be here.

MACDONALD: What do you think about these defense cuts?

ROGERS: Well, to begin with, the president of the United States is the American military's best friend. In 2018, he significantly increased the budget. He's going to do more in 2019. And keep in mind, he is very well aware that we need a strong navy. He is funding the navy to forward deploy them in the Pacific and the Middle East regions to discourage anybody in those regions from attempting to challenge our U.S. military.

In addition to that, remember the space force. He's forward thinking. He's a visionary. He is going to fund that space force to ensure that we're going to have the weapons necessary in the future to defend this country. So what is he talking about? Waste. He's talking about waste. He wants to target waste and get rid of the thousand-dollar hammers that we read about, the 2,500-dollar screwdrivers. He wants to zero in on waste as a good businessman he is. That's where you are going to see cuts.

MACDONALD: You know, the president has been made fun of by the media, really a space force? Well, you know what, Steve, China and Russia is going full bore on that. It is about the space of battle. It's outer space. It's cyber space. And that's the issue, right, Steve?

BARNES: Well, absolutely. Look, I served 25 years of my life in the United States Navy, and I could remember thinking about, what are we going to do in the 21st century? Is anybody going to come with a vision of building a space force? President Trump decides he is going to look towards the future and start building space platforms and weapons --

MACDONALD: OK.

BARNES: -- that will protect us in the years to come.

MACDONALD: Here's the other issue that the critics fail to recognize when they say why are we spending more money on defense. Defense spending protects the powerful status of the U.S. dollar around the world, Steve. It is the world's reserve currency. It is used to price oil and all sorts of global trade. That defense spending helps protect the U.S. dollars. Certainly it's important in the government treasury debt markets, right?

BARNES: Absolutely right. Look, remember the saying peace through strength. A strong economy, a strong military, a strong everything. And look, from the day he took office, he made one priority, and that priority is to protect the American people. And that's exactly what he's delivering on.

MACDONALD: Steve Rogers, great to see you. As a disclosure to you, Steve Rogers is a Trump 2020 campaign advisory board member. Next up, crude oil up 30 cents to 56 in change a barrel today. Month to month, it is down more than 13 percent.

Let's get to your gas prices at the gas pump. The national average price for regular gas, $2.62. It is down more than 40 days straight. Missouri now has the cheapest gas with an average price -- look at that, $2.26. Go Missouri! California, most expensive, $3.64.

To the migrant caravan arrived at the Tijuana border now facing angry protests and clashes from people in Mexico. They don't like it. President Trump said that maybe it is a good time to shut down the government unless he gets money for his border wall. We are going to ask Sean Spicer up next about all of that and more. Stay with us.

MACDONALD: Welcome back. Hundreds of Tijuana citizens protesting the migrant caravan yesterday. They waved signs reading, "no illegals," "no to the invasion," and "Mexico first." Now, the city's mayor, the mayor of Tijuana, even calling the caravan a horde. That's a direct quote from him. He says the caravan is infiltrated by criminals and threatening his community. This as President Trump says it might be a good time to shut down the U.S. government if there is no money for border wall. Homeland Security says there are 500 criminals in the caravans flowing to the border.

Let's take it up with the former White House press secretary. He is senior advisor of America First Action PAC. He is Sean Spicer. Great to see you, Sean.

SEAN SPICER, FORMER WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Hey, Liz, thanks for having me.

MACDONALD: What do you think of the story with the border, Sean?

SPICER: I think it is pretty concerning, right? I think the president has been out in front of this issue talking about it. And in many cases, folks from the left and several folks in the media mocked him. It's a reality now and you can see it full pledge in Tijuana where the mayor and the residents are experiencing what the consequences of having these folks roll through it.

It's a lot more serious. I think people kind of thought it was funny one or not serious rather when it was a few hundred miles away. Now that it's up close and touching on our border, I think the reality of the consequences of these folks coming into our country and the lack of preparedness that we have to deal with this situation is something that President Trump has been ringing the alarm bell on for a while. The reality is now coming home to roost.

MACDONALD: We are showing on the screen with you, Sean, anti-caravan protesters in Tijuana. The mayor of Tijuana, Sean, he is sounding a lot like the president. He says no city would be prepared to receive this tsunami of people. What do you think? Should the president shut down the government over the border wall?

SPICER: I don't know that he has to shut it down. I hope to god that legislators in Congress understand the reality of this. The president has been warning about this, talking about the need to secure the border, talking about protecting our people, but also making sure that we deal with these people in a humanitarian way.

You got two groups of folks. People who truly have an issue but I think more and more and you're seeing this not just from the mayor of Tijuana, but its residents who are saying that this is an invasion, that there are scary and criminal-type people in this caravan. And so I think we better heed the warning and it shouldn't be a partisan thing.

MACDONALD: Right.

SPICER: I think whether or not you are elected as a Republican or Democrat, you should understand the consequences of this.

MACDONALD: Sean, you make an important point because border security isn't some right-wing idea because in 2006, 26 Democrats including Senator Barack Obama, Senator Hillary Clinton, Joe Biden, they voted for a border fence. And just five years ago, Democrats voted yes to a broader security bill.

You know, President Obama, Sean, even said we cannot have people crossing our borders unchecked. And he too sent troops to the Arizona border at one point, right?

SPICER: Absolutely. I think the reality of what we've seeing over the past two and a half -- or two years, rather, is that if President Trump is for it, we got to be against it. There is so much hypocrisy going on and debate right now, policy wise. So as long as President Trump supports it, somehow people have to be against it.

But this shouldn't be something that should divide us. This should be something that unite us, understanding that we are first and foremost a nation of laws, that we can be compassionate and caring for those who need help. But in this particular case, I think the president has been warning about the serious nature of the consequences if we don't protect our border in terms of the type of people who are trying to come into this.

MACDONALD: Right.

SPICER: Again, I would just hope that we shouldn't have to wait until they are climbing over the wall before we recognize that we need to address this in a much better way than it is currently handled.

MACDONALD: Homeland Security now says upwards of 10,500 people are heading to the border. You know, the president making this point too, Sean, that if the migrants fear their home country so much, then why are they waving the flag of Guatemala or Honduras coming in? Your reaction to that?

SPICER? We got a point. I mean, you don't celebrate the country that you're fearful of. It doesn't really make a ton of sense. And I think once -- I have seen a lot of sound from news reports. A lot of these folks are being very clear that this isn't why they are coming here. There is a big difference.

We are losing the discussion about what the need for political asylum is for, people who are truly being persecuted, who are seeking a better life for themselves because of being -- gone after or attacked for their political beliefs. But coming here to seek a job, while it's understandable that you want to make a better life for yourself or your family, is not one of the criteria for political asylum.

MACDONALD: That's a good point. Sean Spicer, come back soon. We love having you on, sir.

SPICER: You bet. Thank you.

MACDONALD: Thank you. Coming up, Democratic senators declare war on President Trump over his appointment for the acting attorney general spot. That is Matthew Whitaker. He filed a lawsuit to try to put break in all of this. We are going to debate it, next. We are going to show you the facts underneath this debate. Stay there.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RUSH LIMBAUGH, TALK SHOW HOST AND CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR: None of any of that should have happened. What do you mean, Rush? The elections were closed. And by law, they had to have a recount. Yeah, yeah, but it wasn't. All of it is so unnecessary. The recounts wouldn't have happened if there had been some concessions.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. Three Democrat senators filing a lawsuit to block President Trump's appointment of Matthew Whitaker as temporary acting attorney general. They claim it deprives the Senate of its constitutional power to sign off on these types of appointments.

Let's take this to the political power panel. Scott Bolden is back with us along with Republican strategist Kurt Schlichter. Kurt, this is legal under the Federal Vacancies Reform Act, right?

KURT SCHLICHTER, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: There is a lot of good arguments there is. There are some people who I really respect who say it isn't. Let's take it to court. Of course, the Democrats have a problem. Let's see if they can get past the standing requirement and even be able to have a judge rule on it.

But, look, I don't have a problem with people fighting over what the constitution means. I think that's vitally forward, and I'm all for it. I just wish they were as picky about the constitution when it came to things like our right to free speech, right to keep in bear arms, right to confront accusers.

MACDONALD: Scott, here is a thing, that act that I just referred to, I mean, President Obama temporarily appointed people without Senate confirmation. So did George W. Bush. You just said you (ph) fill the cabinet post for 210 days. That's it.

SCOTT BOLDEN, ATTORNEY: I think what is bothering people now politically is that under the Federal Vacancies Act, normally the first assistant would fill that role in acting capacity because that individual has been confirmed by the Senate. In this case, it would be Rosenstein. The problem there is we know that Donald Trump would never make him the acting attorney general.

Secondly, you have Whitaker who is believed to be or perceived to be a political hack and a spy for the White House and someone who has spoken against the Mueller investigation. The Democrats are trying to protect the independence of the Mueller investigation.

But my colleague is right about one thing. It is an open question. Republican and Democratic scholars say this might be a good thing. Let a federal judge or even the U.S. Supreme Court decide because the Vacancies Act and the Appointments Clause under the U.S. constitution --

MACDONALD: I hear you.

BOLDEN: -- seem to be inconsistent.

MACDONALD: Rosenstein does support the appointment of Whitaker, Kurt. Here's the thing, I mean, it's 200 days he gets to sit there, does that mean the Mueller probe is going to wrap up before the 200 days is out, Kurt?

SCHLICHTER: It should have wrapped up 200 days ago.

(LAUGHTER)

SCHLICHTER: I knew that was coming. And I think that -- and it's pretty clear that Rosenstein is far too conflicted to be appointed to this position. He should not have been involved in this anyway since he signed off on the FISA warrants.

But, look, this is because the Democrats are afraid that their favorite tool for distracting for the fact that they have no ideas, is this insanity about Russia. It has to end. I hope Whitaker ends it. Put a stake to its heart. Put some garlic on it. Bury it under running water. Get rid of it.

MACDONALD: I'm sure Scott wants to take this. Go ahead, Scott.

BOLDEN: Whitaker certainly wants to do the same you want to do. The problem is he doesn't have the authority to do it. As far as Rosenstein is concerned, you may be right about that, but he has been over the Mueller investigation, given Sessions wasn't available to do it or had to recuse himself.

MACDONALD: Yeah.

BOLDEN: But here the bottom line. What the Democrats really want to avoid is that Whitaker taking acts (ph) when it is unclear he got the authority that even within those 210 days. This is going to try to --

MACDONALD: We are running out of time. Guys, I just think really filing a lawsuit, you have oversight capacity, really got to step it up with another lawsuit. Kurt and Scott, you guys have been terrific. Thank you so much. Say hi to Bidey (ph) for me, Kurt. I love your dog.

(LAUGHTER)

MACDONALD: When is Barkey (ph) coming in to the family?

(LAUGHTER)

SCHLICHTER: Already here.

MACDONALD: OK. Thank you so much.

SCHLICHTER: My dog's name is Bella (ph).

MACDONALD: We got to go. Thank you for having us in your homes. Thank you for watching. Lou Dobbs is next right here on the Fox Business Network. Have a good night.

urn:contentItem:5WK6-K5T1-F03R-N0BT-00000-00Lawmakers want to block tech giants from offering digital currency2019-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:00ZLexisNexisLawmakers want to block tech giants from offering digital currencyChristine Fisher

Jul 15, 2019( Engadget HD: http://www.engadget.com/ Delivered by Newstex) It's been one month since Facebook (and its partners[1]) announced plans to launch Libra[2] cryptocurrency. Already, US lawmakers are calling for Facebook to pause those plans[3]. Now, some legislators want the company to stop altogether. According to Reuters[4], the Democratic majority of the House Financial Services Committee drafted legislation that would prevent big tech companies from functioning as financial institutions or issuing digital currencies.In addition to blocking Facebook's plans for Libra[5], the "Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act" would prevent other firms (those mainly offering an online platform service with at least $25 billion in annual revenue) from launching similar cryptocurrencies.

Companies that violate the rules could be fined as much as $1 million per day.As Reuters notes, it's unlikely the legislation will pass, but it does reveal a growing attitude of skepticism[6] toward big tech companies, especially those looking to enter the financial services[7] realm. Tomorrow, Facebook plans to assure US lawmakers[8] that it won't launch Libra until the regulatory concerns are addressed. David Marcus, head of Facebook's digital wallet, released a prepared statement[9] promising that Libra is not being built to compete with sovereign currencies or interfere with monetary policy. Given Facebook's track record[10] of handling things like data privacy and the skepticism around Libra, it's too soon to say if that will be enough. urn:contentItem:5YS3-2KJ1-DXKX-00J4-00000-00Lawmakers warn coronavirus contact-tracing is ripe for abusive surveillance2020-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:00ZLexisNexisLawmakers warn coronavirus contact-tracing is ripe for abusive surveillance

Apr 26, 2020( PolitiCal: https://www.latimes.com/politicsDelivered by Newstex) It is a big promise from Silicon Valley to a nation looking for ways to be freed from home confinement: Smartphones could discreetly detect those who may have COVID-19 and nudge them to quarantine, blunting renewed outbreaks as Americans start to once again venture out.But as tech firms lay the foundation for a potentially massive digital contact-tracing infrastructure, Washington is grappling with whether such technology can work without becoming a hulking, invasive surveillance system.It is a vexing problem that could leave Americans exposed to another vast intrusion in their everyday lives[1] by governments or big tech companies.Apple and Google, which are leading the efforts to develop tracking apps, have pledged that participation would be voluntary and include guardrails to protect confidentiality. But the inability of Congress to pass meaningful data-privacy rules and the poor track record of many tech firms in protecting privacy heightens the risk, lawmakers and outside experts say. Advertisement 'If information about who has COVID-19 gets into the wrong hands, it could lead to things that are harmful,' said Rep. Anna G. Eshoo (D-Menlo Park).She is among several lawmakers calling on the Trump administration to place strict limits on what contact-tracing data can be collected and shared.

The White House has so far issued none, even as it consults behind closed doors with tech firms on the development of a tracing infrastructure.'Without a national privacy law, this is a black hole,' Eshoo said.The technology, which Google and Apple plan to launch in mid-May, enables people to have their phone track the Bluetooth signals emitted by the phones of every other person with whom they come in close contact. Advertisement If a person tests positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus, an app provided by their public health department would send an alert to all other users of the app with whom the infected person had contact over the previous two weeks. Identities would not be revealed, just the day of the contact, how long it lasted, and the strength of the Bluetooth signal. Privacy experts voice two big fears:Such a system would only be useful if it's widely used. It's unclear if tracing technology can be effective at all if the entire system is anonymous, voluntary and inhibits the creation of large surveillance databases. So once a system is launched, there will inevitably be pressure to require some people to use it.And if the system is widely used and especially if it's connected to a database there will be a huge risk that data would live on well beyond the pandemic, giving governments and corporations easy access to information about people's movements and healthcare needs that eclipses what they now have. Advertisement 'What I am afraid of is some folks in the tech community will use this huge public need as a way to be invasive with private data and create a beachfront in the health sector,' said Sen. Mark R. Warner (D-Va.), a technology entrepreneur himself.'It is not like the big platforms are coming at this with clean hands.'Before the pandemic hit, Warner was already investigating collaborations tech firms were forging with big healthcare and fitness companies.Access to healthcare data could enable tech companies to build profiles of people's ailments and needs, exposing them to targeted marketing campaigns, and also to potential discrimination by employers, insurance companies, landlords or others. Advertisement Existing healthcare privacy rules don't protect Americans from many of those intrusions, and even those regulations are being eased to give medical professionals flexibility as they deal with the deluge of COVID-19 patients. The potential for tech companies to aggressively move into this area has many privacy analysts unnerved.'These companies have been lobbying all along to get the government to look the other way while they grab our healthcare information to more effectively monetize it,' said Jeffrey Chester, executive director of the Center for Digital Democracy, a group that advocates for digital privacy.'We have to get a handle on this pandemic, but we also have to look at the motivations here.'On the other side of the debate are people like Stewart Baker, who served as assistant secretary of Homeland Security in the George W. Bush administration and, earlier, as general counsel of the National Security Agency. Advertisement 'If you asked Americans in February 2020, are they prepared to have the governor of their state tell them to go home, stay home and lose their jobs, everyone would have said no. Yet here we are,' Baker said.Baker is urging tech companies to embrace the type of monitoring system deployed in Singapore[2], where the government is collecting large amounts of Bluetooth-generated data on the movements of citizens and their social contacts and notifying anyone with a contact who later turns out to be infected.'It is a trivial intrusion on our liberty as citizens when you compare it to all the other things during this pandemic where we have said, 'This is necessary, we will do it,'' he said.Lawmakers who have taken the lead in investigating the exploitation and abuse of user data by big tech firms worry that the point of view Baker expresses is gaining currency in the White House, as officials meet behind closed doors to develop a strategy for contact tracing. They warn of implications that could last far beyond the pandemic. Advertisement When the idea of contact-tracing apps first emerged, there were optimistic predictions that America could lean on its tech pioneers to help safely reopen the economy without the privacy intrusions embedded in tracking apps[3] in China, Taiwan and South Korea.That optimism, however, is fast fading. Even countries such as France and Germany, which adhere to strict privacy laws, are drafting plans for data-collection systems that step around those rules so public health bureaucracies can identify who went where, when they went there and most importantly who they may have come in contact with along the way.Some prominent computer scientists involved in building contact-tracing tools in Europe are alarmed by the direction that governments there are headed.The group, called the DP-3T Project, had been pushing a privacy-oriented approach similar to what Apple and Google have discussed alert systems that keep the data collected anonymous and largely confined to the phones of users who opt in. Advertisement By contrast, the contact-tracing tools some European leaders are now pursuing 'can easily be turned into an instrument of surveillance with considerable human rights implications,' the group warned in a recent white paper.The apps that American technology firms are developing are voluntary in theory, but companies could make their use a condition of employment, said Ashkan Soltani, a security researcher and former chief technologist for the Federal Trade Commission during the Obama administration.'They alert the employer whether you have been in contact with someone who has been infected,' Soltani said. But, he said, the technology is full of gaps and could potentially label employees at risk when it should not.A Bluetooth signal might be unaware that an infected individual who appeared to be in close proximity to an employee was on the other side of a wall, for example. Nor would the technology be able to register that a person identified as being at risk was wearing protective gear when they had a brush with contagion while shopping. Advertisement Newsletter Get our Essential Politics newsletter The latest news, analysis and insights from our bureau chiefs in Sacramento and D.C. You may occasionally receive promotional content from the Los Angeles Times. In some nations that are already aggressively relying on digital tracking, the technologies are far more intrusive. Taiwan is collecting personal insurance and passport travel records, as it tracks down who might be infected and orders them to quarantine.Countries that use such systems are also digitally tagging people with different color codings, which determine whether they are permitted to move freely in public.Officials at Apple and Google say their infrastructure is designed to avoid such intrusion. Yet Washington is full of questions about whether it can be effective if the companies abide by that pledge and also whether these companies with a dismal record on privacy[4] can be trusted to be in the driver's seat at all. Advertisement Google and Apple, at least, are acutely aware of the optics. On Friday, the companies distributed a FAQ to consumers stressing that the data accumulated by them will be anonymous, impossible to monetize and will stop being collected after the pandemic.The assurances have yet to assuage lawmakers such as Republican Sen. Josh Hawley of Missouri, a fierce critic of technology firms, who sent a letter to the CEOs of both companies last week.'Americans are right to be skeptical of this project,' he wrote. 'Too often, Americans have been burned by companies who calculated that the profits they could gain by reversing privacy pledges would outweigh any later financial penalty.'Hawley challenged the executives to hold themselves personally liable financially if the firms break their privacy pledge. Advertisement So far, the executives have not made that commitment. urn:contentItem:5YS6-9641-JCBJ-Y1SR-00000-00Lawmakers warn coronavirus contact-tracing is ripe for abusive surveillance;Apple and Google say there are guardrails to protect confidentiality.2020-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:00ZLexisNexisNEWSHealthLawmakers warn coronavirus contact-tracing is ripe for abusive surveillanceApple and Google say there are guardrails to protect confidentiality.Tribune News Service

WASHINGTON - It is a big promise from Silicon Valley to a nation looking for ways to be freed from home confinement: Smartphones could discreetly detect those who may have COVID-19 and nudge them to quarantine, blunting renewed outbreaks as Americans start to once again venture out.

But as tech firms lay the foundation for a potentially massive digital contact-tracing infrastructure, Washington is grappling with whether such technology can work without becoming a hulking, invasive surveillance system.

It is a vexing problem that could leave Americans exposed to another vast intrusion in their everyday lives by governments or big tech companies.

Apple and Google, which are leading the efforts to develop tracking apps, have pledged that participation would be voluntary and include guardrails to protect confidentiality. But the inability of Congress to pass meaningful data-privacy rules - and the poor track record of many tech firms in protecting privacy - heightens the risk, lawmakers and outside experts say.

"If information about who has COVID-19 gets into the wrong hands, it could lead to things that are harmful," said Rep. Anna G. Eshoo (D-Menlo Park).

She is among several lawmakers calling on the Trump administration to place strict limits on what contact-tracing data can be collected and shared. The White House has so far issued none, even as it consults behind closed doors with tech firms on the development of a tracing infrastructure.

"Without a national privacy law, this is a black hole," Eshoo said.

The technology, which Google and Apple plan to launch in mid-May, enables people to have their phone track the Bluetooth signals emitted by the phones of every other person with whom they come in close contact.

If a person tests positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus, an app provided by their public health department would send an alert to all other users of the app with whom the infected person had contact over the previous two weeks. Identities would not be revealed, just the day of the contact, how long it lasted, and the strength of the Bluetooth signal.

Privacy experts voice two big fears:

Such a system would only be useful if it's widely used. It's unclear if tracing technology can be effective at all if the entire system is anonymous, voluntary and inhibits the creation of large surveillance databases. So once a system is launched, there will inevitably be pressure to require some people to use it.

And if the system is widely used - and especially if it's connected to a database - there will be a huge risk that data would live on well beyond the pandemic, giving governments and corporations easy access to information about people's movements and healthcare needs that eclipses what they now have.

"What I am afraid of is some folks in the tech community will use this huge public need as a way to be invasive with private data and create a beachfront in the health sector," said Sen. Mark R. Warner (D-Va.), a technology entrepreneur himself.

"It is not like the big platforms are coming at this with clean hands."

Before the pandemic hit, Warner was already investigating collaborations tech firms were forging with big healthcare and fitness companies.

Access to healthcare data could enable tech companies to build profiles of people's ailments and needs, exposing them to targeted marketing campaigns, and also to potential discrimination by employers, insurance companies, landlords or others.

Existing healthcare privacy rules don't protect Americans from many of those intrusions, and even those regulations are being eased to give medical professionals flexibility as they deal with the deluge of COVID-19 patients. The potential for tech companies to aggressively move into this area has many privacy analysts unnerved.

"These companies have been lobbying all along to get the government to look the other way while they grab our healthcare information to more effectively monetize it," said Jeffrey Chester, executive director of the Center for Digital Democracy, a group that advocates for digital privacy.

"We have to get a handle on this pandemic, but we also have to look at the motivations here."

On the other side of the debate are people like Stewart Baker, who served as assistant secretary of Homeland Security in the George W. Bush administration and, earlier, as general counsel of the National Security Agency.

"If you asked Americans in February 2020, are they prepared to have the governor of their state tell them to go home, stay home and lose their jobs, everyone would have said no. Yet here we are," Baker said.

Baker is urging tech companies to embrace the type of monitoring system deployed in Singapore, where the government is collecting large amounts of Bluetooth-generated data on the movements of citizens and their social contacts and notifying anyone with a contact who later turns out to be infected.

"It is a trivial intrusion on our liberty as citizens when you compare it to all the other things during this pandemic where we have said, 'This is necessary, we will do it,'" he said.

Lawmakers who have taken the lead in investigating the exploitation and abuse of user data by big tech firms worry that the point of view Baker expresses is gaining currency in the White House, as officials meet behind closed doors to develop a strategy for contact tracing. They warn of implications that could last far beyond the pandemic.

When the idea of contact-tracing apps first emerged, there were optimistic predictions that America could lean on its tech pioneers to help safely reopen the economy without the privacy intrusions embedded in tracking apps in China, Taiwan and South Korea.

That optimism, however, is fast fading. Even countries such as France and Germany, which adhere to strict privacy laws, are drafting plans for data-collection systems that step around those rules so public health bureaucracies can identify who went where, when they went there and - most importantly - who they may have come in contact with along the way.

Some prominent computer scientists involved in building contact-tracing tools in Europe are alarmed by the direction that governments there are headed.

The group, called the DP-3T Project, had been pushing a privacy-oriented approach similar to what Apple and Google have discussed - alert systems that keep the data collected anonymous and largely confined to the phones of users who opt in.

By contrast, the contact-tracing tools some European leaders are now pursuing "can easily be turned into an instrument of surveillance with considerable human rights implications," the group warned in a recent white paper.

The apps that American technology firms are developing are voluntary in theory, but companies could make their use a condition of employment, said Ashkan Soltani, a security researcher and former chief technologist for the Federal Trade Commission during the Obama administration.

"They alert the employer whether you have been in contact with someone who has been infected," Soltani said. But, he said, the technology is full of gaps and could potentially label employees at risk when it should not.

A Bluetooth signal might be unaware that an infected individual who appeared to be in close proximity to an employee was on the other side of a wall, for example. Nor would the technology be able to register that a person identified as being at risk was wearing protective gear when they had a brush with contagion while shopping.

In some nations that are already aggressively relying on digital tracking, the technologies are far more intrusive. Taiwan is collecting personal insurance and passport travel records, as it tracks down who might be infected and orders them to quarantine.

Countries that use such systems are also digitally tagging people with different color codings, which determine whether they are permitted to move freely in public.

Officials at Apple and Google say their infrastructure is designed to avoid such intrusion. Yet Washington is full of questions about whether it can be effective if the companies abide by that pledge - and also whether these companies with a dismal record on privacy can be trusted to be in the driver's seat at all.

Google and Apple, at least, are acutely aware of the optics. On Friday, the companies distributed a FAQ to consumers stressing that the data accumulated by them will be anonymous, impossible to monetize and will stop being collected after the pandemic.

The assurances have yet to assuage lawmakers such as Republican Sen. Josh Hawley of Missouri, a fierce critic of technology firms, who sent a letter to the CEOs of both companies last week.

"Americans are right to be skeptical of this project," he wrote. "Too often, Americans have been burned by companies who calculated that the profits they could gain by reversing privacy pledges would outweigh any later financial penalty."

Hawley challenged the executives to hold themselves personally liable financially if the firms break their privacy pledge.

So far, the executives have not made that commitment.

urn:contentItem:5HC4-7DD1-DY2D-J0MX-00000-00Law nerd hits gambling gorillas2015-11-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:00ZLexisNexisEDITORIALPg. 25Law nerd hits gambling gorillasBY HARRY SIEGEL

For once, government landed a solid first punch.

The go-to call in the new playbook of big-tech disruption - much of it crafted by Democratic campaign veterans getting handsomely paid by companies with multi-billion dollar market caps to doll them up as friends of the middle-class housewife and the working stiff - is to get big, fast, ignoring rules as needed. Then, consent to some regulation that stops competitors from scaling up the way you did.

That's what DraftKings and FanDuel, the two 800-pound gorillas of the daily fantasy sports world - effectively major-sports-league-endorsed gambling sites - had been doing. In just a few years, they came from nowhere to become ESPN's biggest advertisers by far while taking in twice the action of the Vegas sports books and growing fast. Their endless ads boil down to the pitch that if you're smart enough to watch sports, you should probably be making money betting on them.

After beginning to probe reports a DraftKings employee had used inside information to win big on FanDuel, Attorney General Eric Schneiderman gave no warning before dropping a much bigger case-and-desist hammer Tuesday, telling the sites they were in violation of New York's constitution.

As the facing editorial details, the state bans staking "something of value upon the outcome of a contest of chance or a future contingent event" outside of the bettor's direct control, even if skill is also a factor. Like, say, football players' stat lines.

Pathetically, the companies seemed unprepared for this obvious, accurate hit. Never mind our TV ads, FanDuel CEO Nigel Eccles told reporters Wednesday, the sharks win, and win big, proving that fantasy betting is a skill game. That's not only cynical as hell, but a skill-luck distinction that has no bearing on New York's law.

It all sounds a lot like the poker world, right down to player concerns about cheaters and bots and big companies trying to keep the cash coming in while staying a step ahead of pesky regulators. In fact, many of the top fantasy players - who enter each tournament hundreds of times and use their own custom-built models to ensure a return on their investment - are former poker pros who followed the sucker's money here after the Justice Department effectively shut down online poker in 2011.

What the fantasy-sports guys have that the poker guys did not is sign-in from the sports leagues, which appreciate obsessive fans or Stans who stay tuned to bad games and garbage time plays to see how "their players" are "producing."

With hardly a legal leg to stand on in New York, FanDuel has called another option from the tech play book, weaponizing its customers. (That's not new, but it's been super-charged by the Web, as when Uber earlier this year used its drivers and customers to put tire tracks on Mayor de Blasio's back after he cynically tried to freeze the service). Eccles boasted there have already been 10,000 calls to Schneiderman's office protesting the cease-and-desist letter.

The company, he said, wasn't ginning up opposition but trying to channel dedicated fans' natural anger to stand up for the little guy against the AG's "very extreme and sudden decision that New Yorkers are not capable of making their own decisions," adding that "the simple reason that hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers play fantasy sports is because it's fun."

Why does law nerd hate fun?

Absurdly, Eccles denied FanDuel was a gambling site, saying that while they collect entry fees and pay out winners, they're just middlemen, not staked in the action. Just like Uber says it's not in the car-ride business and Airbnb says it's not a hotelier.

Shucks, we're just people connecting people, and taking a cut for making it possible.

But Uber and Airbnb at least make credible cases they're providing public goods the market and its regulators had failed to. FanDuel? It's on "a mission to make sports more exciting to everyone in the U.S."

Shucks. But this isn't just a sped-up version of traditional season-long fantasy leagues. It's a model that depends on a steady supply of suckers to throw money into the endless tide of numbers sporting events throw off, enough money to feed the companies and the sharks.

Consider the pitch a nascent competitor sent The News Wednesday, suggesting that the fantasy sites' new legal issues would make a nice hook for a story about their new real-time "sports prediction game" that'll let you bet on every element of every down of every NFL game - "more than 15,000 picks per game," with "dynamically changing odds" after each play.

Daily action is so 2014. Why wait for 60 minutes, let alone for Monday, when now "you know immediately if you've won"? Who could be against that?

Thanks, Mr. Attorney General.

hsiegel@nydailynews.com

urn:contentItem:5RTX-STP1-JDN8-2008-00000-00Laws needed to crack down on cyberbullying2018-03-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:00ZLexisNexisPg. 44Laws needed to crack down on cyberbullying

NEW laws that would see big tech companies such as Facebook, Google and Twitter liable for harm caused by cyberbullying and violence are urgently needed to ensure social media platforms have a strong financial incentive to stamp out harmful behaviour online.

For too long, social media platforms have helped to enable cyberbullying without ever being held to account for the harm caused, including injury and death.

Politicians should approach the need to make cyberspace safe much in the same way that our current laws require workplaces to be safe by imposing a duty of care on the big tech companies and by allowing individuals to sue when that duty is breached.

Groups such as Facebookand Twitter are often quick to distance themselves from instances of cyberbullying, when what they should be doing is taking decisive action to minimise such behaviour on their platforms and in making sure people are protected.

While we welcome comments from Minister Kelly O'Dwyer warning Facebookand Twitter to lift their standards, governments have typically taken a timid approach to regulation in this area. Even criminal acts in cyberspace are rarely prosecuted.

Europe is leading the charge on regulating the internet but Australian legislators are lagging behind.

New Zealand introduced its own anti-cyberbullying legislation in 2015.

That's why we believe regulatory responsibility is urgently needed to prompt greater action from social media platforms to act on cyberbullying and violence.

If victims had the tools to take on groups such as Facebookand Twitter, then those companies would be compelled to commit serious resources to clean up their platforms.

We also want to see enforceable sanctions against employers who fail to protect against cyberbullying in workplaces.

In today's world, there is an increasing expectation for staff to be actively engaged with social media for their work, in industries such as the media in particular, yet many employers are not taking steps to protect their staff from the obvious risks that can come with this.

John Bornstein is principal of Maurice Blackburn Lawyers.

urn:contentItem:5W46-V371-JBJ7-N2XH-00000-00Laws not promises needed to regulate big tech2019-05-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:00ZLexisNexisLaws not promises needed to regulate big techPaul Smith

ACCC chief Rod Sims has warned governments against accepting their promises of big tech companies to do better at policing content as experts call for global laws.

Australian Competition and Consumer Commission chairman Rod Sims has warned that regulation rather than positive statements of intent will be required to force big technology companies to properly police the content broadcast on their networks, after some of the world's biggest firms signed a pledge to do better.

Mr Sims joined experts in welcoming a "Christchurch Call" statement, announced by New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern and French President Emmanuel Macron overnight on Wednesday, in which tech giants including Facebook, Google, Twitter, Amazon and Microsoft said they would increase their efforts to stamp out the circulation of abhorrent material such as the Christchurch terror shootings.

However the lack of firm details about what the companies would do differently and the absence of any legislative measures to compel tech companies to change, led experts to advocate for UN-style inter-governmental cooperation to formulate enforceable international laws.

"The agreement shows that the large platforms can do much more in this area, which makes sense but is different to what they have been previously saying," Mr Sims told The Australian Financial Review from Colombia, where he is attending a conference for competition regulators.

"These issues are of such importance that it is hard to see self regulation, while welcome, being sufficient. This is particularly the case given past reluctance by the platforms to move in this area."

As part of its Digital Platforms Inquiry draft report late last year, the ACCC called on the federal government to overhaul the patchwork of regulations "to effectively and consistently regulate the conduct of all entities which perform comparable functions in the production and delivery of content in Australia".

The ACCC proposed "meaningful sanctions" for entities that breach the laws, regardless of whether they are online companies such as Facebook, or more traditional media companies.

The Christchurch Call statement mentioned a range of measures from government and tech providers, including tech companies developing tools to prevent the upload of terrorist and violent extremist content; social moves to counter the roots of violent extremism; increasing transparency around the removal and detection of online content, and reviewing how companies' algorithms direct users to violent extremist content.

Grateful for PM @jacindaardern's leadership. Open, practical, and collaborative. Our commitment will be the same.   https://t.co/UBqE1ozG2Y

??? jack (@jack) May 15, 2019

Asked for specific changes it was going to make a Facebook spokesman told the Financial Review that plans announced on Tuesday to suspend users that violate standards from live streaming for a set period of time, would combine with other investments to make a genuine attempt to address concerns.

"We know that these threats require technical innovation to stay ahead of the type of adversarial media manipulation we saw after the Christchurch attacks. To support this, Facebook will invest $US7.5 million ($10.85 million) in new research partnerships with leading academics from three universities, designed to improve image and video analysis technology," he said.

"We're improving our matching technology so that we can stop the spread of viral videos of this nature, regardless of how they were originally produced.

"Our COO, Sheryl Sandberg, also recently shared some of the additional steps we're taking to stop the spread of hate online, including the use of our existing artificial intelligence tools to identify and remove a range of hate groups in Australia and New Zealand, including the Lads Society, the United Patriots Front, the Antipodean Resistance, and National Front New Zealand."

Distinguished Professor of Public Communication at the University of Technology Sydney Jim Macnamara said while it was a positive step for the likes of Facebook and Twitter to acknowledge and pledge to tackle the problems publicly, it was likely that governments would ultimately have to find a way to legislate the global online arena.

In the aftermath of the Christchurch shootings the Australian government enacted laws that could mean tech industry executives face up to three years in jail and their companies fined hundreds of millions of dollars if they allow their platforms to be used to broadcast "abhorrent violence" material including terrorist attacks, murders and rapes.

However Professor Macnamara said the global nature of big social sites meant individual country laws were unlikely to make a meaningful difference to how the platforms operated.

"Pulling companies together internationally is essential because these things happen across borders and you can't address the problem in any one jurisdiction," he said.

"Self regulation is part of the solution, but I think governments need to collaboratively consider legislation ... If governments got together under a UN kind of arrangement and agreed on certain principles, you could aim for an Interpol style set up, where if something happens in one country they could collaborate to tackle it."

Despite 17 countries and the European Commission signing on to support the Christchurch Call, it received a notable snub for the United States, the home of the big tech companies, which declined to be involved on freedom of speech grounds.
